question: Question_01_(c)
statement:
\emph{For this short-answer question, only the answers (placed in the
boxes) will be marked.}

Find the derivative of

\[\displaystyle
f(x) = \left( \ln(x^2+1) \right)^3\]
sols:
We want to use the chain rule. So let the outer function
\emph{$f$}(\emph{x}) = \emph{x}\textsuperscript{3} and the inner function
\emph{g}(\emph{x}) = ln(\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2}+1). Then

\begin{align*}
\left[\left(\ln(x^2+1)\right)^3\right]' &= \left[f(g(x))\right]' \\
&= f'(g(x)) g'(x) \\
&= 3(g(x))^2 \left[\ln(x^2+1)\right]' \\
&= 3(\ln(x^2+1))^2 \left[\ln(x^2+1)\right]'
\end{align*}

In order to find the derivative of ln(\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2}+1) we
use the chain rule again. So let's set \emph{h}(\emph{x}) = ln(\emph{x})
and \emph{k}(\emph{x}) = \emph{x}\textsuperscript{2}+1. Then

\begin{align*}
\left[\ln(x^2+1)\right]' &= \left[h(k(x))\right]' \\
&= h'(k(x)) k'(x) \\
&= \frac1{k(x)} 2x \\
&= \frac{2x}{x^2+1}
\end{align*}

Putting these results together we get our final answer:

\[\left[\left(\ln(x^2+1)\right)^3\right]' = 3(\ln(x^2+1))^2 \frac{2x}{x^2+1}\]
hints: You will need the chain rule, twice.
